Schools remain closed until 1 June 2020
Grade 7 and 12 to return from 1 June 2020
Subject to proper sanitation, use of PPE, santisers, hand washing soap, gloves, cloth masks and thermometers
Educators and learners to be screened on entry. Those with raised temperature will be considered for isolation
Physical distancing including no more than two learners sharing desks and no hugging or handshaking
Schools are expected to sanitise classrooms prior to start of each school day
Learners to sanitise hands before entering classrooms
Movement of learners between classes will be limited
School transport to undergo santisation prior to start of all trips
Cloth fask masks to be worn by all students and teachers at all times
All sports matches, choral practices, eisteddfods and festivals will be prohibted

Wellness visits to be postponed
All clinical and surgical interventions that do not pose harm to the animal's health and welfare must be postponed
Routine vaccination can be postponed if the owner is able to manage the animal to minimise the risk of exposure until the animal can be vaccinated
Routine diagnostic monitoring and testing should be postponed unless there are valid reasons that a delay would compromise the health and welfare of the animal
Boarding, day care, grooming and other ancillary services
Sterilisations, dehorning and other related procedures to be postponed unless non-performance may affect the health and welfare of the animal
Routine post mortems must be postponed

Pet food, accessories, health products and treats
Selected veterinary services, conditions apply:
Treatment of sick and injured animals that cannot be postponed
Minimum number of assistants should remain available
Adminster boosters of vaccine series that have started if deemed necessary based on animal's condition and circumstances (e.g. risk of exposure)
Control of parasites must be limited to instanced where the delays to provide treatment may negatively affect the health and welfare of animals
Routine services including post-operative check-ups must be provided through telemedicine
Sterilisations, dehorning and other related procedures under emergency situations
Post mortems which necessitate urgent diagnosis to prevent spread of disease or high morbidities and mortalities may be performed
Maintaining productivity of dairy animals e.g. interventions to support breeding cycle and udder health of dairy animals may continue
Services relating to control of animal diseases may be implemented, subject to directions
Veterinary diagnostic services for animal diseases and food safety to continue
Veterinarians are required to wear proper personal protective equipment (PPE) at all times
Drop offs of medicines and usage of e-commerce must be implemented to reduce human physical interaction
